narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Intro physics topics including kinematics and dynamics with a few other topics mixed in.

This course covered kinematics, dynamics, rotational motion, energy, and oscillations. I learned about forces and acceleration and friction and rolling and rotation. This class helped me grow my problem solving skills.
Dynamics, kinematics, waves, oscillations.
Introductory level Mechanics and Oscillations.
I re-developed my math skills as well as a lot of problem solving and critical thinking as it applies to physics.
I learned about the fundamentals of mechanics.
How to figure out what will happen to various physical systems
I developed tools to understand physics and to solve problems.
Lots of physics. The intro level. How to apply physics to other problems.
I learned that physics is not as scary as I thought it was.
All general physics knowledge.
newtonian physics, dynamics, waves, etc

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great intro course.

I did not feel that this course taught much more than high school AP physics 1 which I already took. I wish less time was spent on simple topics like kinematics and more time was spent explaining the more complex areas and helping students get an intuitive understanding that was deeper than the equations.

This course covered a lot of content but not overwhelmingly. The exam content was relevant to class materials and it was easy to know what you needed to study for. However, a few more problem solving sessions would have been helpful, in addition to covering why kinematics equations work.

Strengths: Homework load is very manageable. There were plenty office hours offered if you needed help. 

Weaknesses: Reading the chapter ahead of time REALLY helps, but he doesn't tell you what chapter we'll be going over that week. Otherwise, lectures were hard to follow and he rarely summarized key points so everything was just kind of lost. Quizzes asked for information that was not in the textbook or taught in lecture. The tests included a lot of examples where you didn't have numerical values, but just the variables. Very confusing.

I think that the class is very accommodating to beginners of Physics and does not have us do the same problems over and over, which I really appreciate. I personally do not like lectures with attendance as a grade component.

The professor was a big strength, and I felt the weekly psets were generally helpful for learning the content. One weakness was that the content moved very quickly and tended to get ahead of the assignments, making it sometimes difficult to switch gears or learn the newer content in class when you may not have figured out the previous content that it builds on yet.

The pace of the course is very quick, but reasonable depending on the background of the students. I believe that if this was the first physics course a student had taken, then it would be much more difficult to follow along. Nonetheless, the professor goes over many example problems which is very helpful.
The course was pretty effective in going over physics concepts. I do think it would have been beneficial to have more practice problems in class.

This course is unorganized and goes very quickly. The professor is used to teaching during the summer, so I'm guessing he used the same course time as the summer. This made the class hard to follow and we also learned topics that were not relevant for the course.

Strengths: GREAT PROFESSOR!! Kept class engaging, super thoughtful, incredible support from TA's and Prof.
Weaknesses: goes a little fast through lectures
The lectures go super fast, but then he offers 2 weeks at the end for review before reading period. Having discussion section would have made the class much better.

Overall the course was taught well, but it was sometimes hard to follow problems when they written out due to the different colors and papers being used. Also, I would have liked to have required mandatory sections, which I believe were cancelled because of scheduling conflicts. I think this would have pushed me to learn the material earlier and better, as I often forgot or didn't make use of office hours.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course really could have been asynchronous, because it was a lecture class with no real "Live" requirement.
The online lecture format was fine, there could have beengreater engagement, but the drawings were always easy to see and the professor did his best to answer questions.
Recorded lectures are great. Proctored tests were kind of annoying.
I think it feels like a regular lecture, nothing much to comment.
The live lectures recorded were helpful.
The projector was a good choice in terms of lecture, instead of iPads or other note taking devices that may be glitchy.
It went as best as it could for a covid semester! Being close to email support was very helpful
With all the limitations of covid this class went very well. I only wish there were discussion sections.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Good intro class.
Yes if you have to take physics for your major/for pre med.
If you need to take physics, then yes,  I do recommend.

I have no idea why you would take this class besides fulfilling major requirements but if you're looking for a fun time, look somewhere else. If you're looking for math, you'll get it, but it's basic.
Yes, I do not know how good the regular sequence is, but I feel like it is hard to be better than this.
If it's required or you're into physics, it's not too bad. Otherwise there are probably other courses for you.

Yes, you learn a lot in the class, but it is important to keep up with it. The professor goes very quick during lecture, but is very welcoming and helpful during office hours, so it is important to talk to him afterwards if you have any questions.
Not unless you have to take it or really like physics.
It's a good course for anyone interested in physics.

Absolutely! The material itself was very challenging in the since that it's physics, but the class offers loads of support to ensure your success. Additionally Prof. MG is wonderful and made physics one of my favorite classes even though it's not required for any aspect of my major.
Physics is probably a prereq for you so you gotta take it anyway. It's not too bad. Prof Ghiassi is a good one to have. His psets and exams are very manageable.
YES
